item.title: Cesium
Sending Email Correctly in .NET
item.description:
Get 30% off everything on Dometrain: https://dometrain.com/courses/?ref=nick-chapsas&promo=youtube&coupon_code=SUMMER30 Subscribe to my weekly newsletter: https://nickchapsas.com
Hello, everybody. I'm Nick, and in this video, Dylan Beattie will show you to properly and correctly send emails in .NET. Sending emails is a fundamental feature of almost every application and understanding how to do it properly is one of the most important things you can do to get an edge over other developers.
Subscribe to Dylan Beattie: https://www.youtube.com/dylanbeattie
Workshops: https://bit.ly/nickworkshops
Don't forget to comment, like and subscribe :)
Social Media: Follow me on GitHub: https://github.com/Elfocrash Follow me on Twitter: https://twitter.com/nickchapsas Connect on LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/nick-chapsas
#csharp #dotnet

item.title: Why You Should Add Indexes to Foreign Key Refs in PostgreSQL
item.description:
Overview
When building a data model for PostgreSQL, you're more than likely to have foreign keys to define relationships between tables. When you have those foreign keys, one quick way to optimize your queries and allow them to be significantly faster is to index on those foreign key references.
Reference

item.title: Intel Outside: Hacking every Intel employee and various internal websites
item.description: Hardcoded credentials, pointless encryption, and generous APIs exposed details of every employee and made it possible to break into internal websites.

item.title: Language Models as Thespians
item.description: Thinking of language models as actors is an effective way to understand their quirks, predict their failures, and get better results when using them.

item.title: Individual URL compression experiment initial thoughts
item.description: I've made some experiments with compressing individual URLs, and I describe my initial observations (while comparing to standard compression algorithms).

item.title: Qutting GitHub
item.description: I’ve had this post sitting in my drafts since April. I decided to finish it in light of the news that GitHub is no longer independent inside Microsoft and going full-tilt into AI slop. I’ve decided to migrate all of my personal projects1 off GitHub— come join me. Going forward, my public work will be on https://codeberg.org/jpt/ Read on if you’d like to understand why, or you can skip to Where To? if you’d like to make a similar move.

item.title: RAG-Shot Learning - Joseph Cooper
item.description: RAG-enhanced few-shot learning improves LLM performance by retrieving relevant labeled examples during inference, eliminating the need for fine-tuning while achieving comparable results.

item.title: How Large Language Models Parse Content
item.description: An insightful exploration into how Large Language Models parse and understand content, highlighting the importance of structure, verifiable claims, and semantic density in AI comprehension.

item.title: Optimising for trust
item.description: TDD, BDD, DDD, Agile, SAFe, Scrum, Kanban, XP… there’s a lot of ways to skin a cat write code in a professional environment. I take pride in being a person who is a non-ideologue when it comes to my code. There are many good ways of working, and they are all context-dependent. You can’t apply the same things that worked when you were a two-person startup operating out of the proverbial garage and expect them to work once your hypothetical unicorn has reached a thousand-plus developers. Even within the same organisation, processes that work for one team can be catastrophic when applied to their neighbouring team.

item.title: Big Tech Employee Giving Program Tier List
item.description: Which tech companies offer the best employee donation matching programs? I ranked FAANG and other Big Tech firms by their charitable giving benefits to find out which employer helps their employees give the most.

item.title: The Incredible Demo Scene - Making Art with Code
item.description:
A look at the incredible demo scene - how coders and musicians turn ones and zeros into art. The demo scene represents artistic creativity and technical ability. Pushing the limits that we were thought were possible. In this episode we look at the Demo Scene, its roots, history, the effects, The Demo Scene on game consoles and even code our own copper bars for fun. Please Enjoy!
Demos Featured In this Episode:
